resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
kou opened a new pull request #11263:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11263


   Summary:
   
   Generating metadata for APT/Yum repositories from all .deb/.rpm
   on local from scratch
   
       ||
       \/
   
   Generating metadata for APT/Yum repositories only for built .deb/.rpm
   and merging the generated metadata and existing metadata
   (Released .deb/.rpm aren't downloaded.)
   
   Before:
   
     For RC:
       1. Download built .deb/.rpm for RC
       2. Sign the built .deb/.rpm
       3. Upload the signed built .deb/.rpm to
          https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...}-rc
       3. Download all released .deb/.rpm from
          https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...}
       4. Download the all built and signed .deb/.rpm from
          https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...}-rc
       5. Generate metadata for APT/Yum repositories with local .deb/.rpm
          from scratch
       6. Upload the metadata for APT/Yum repositories to
          https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...}-rc
   
     For release:
       1. Download the all .deb/.rpm and metadata for APT/Yum repositories from
          https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...}-rc
       2. Upload the downloaded files to
          https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...}
   
   After:
   
     For RC:
       1. Download the built .deb/.rpm for RC
       2. Sign the built .deb/.rpm
       3. Generate metadata for APT/Yum repositories for the built and
          signed .deb/.rpm
       4. Download metadata for APT/Yum repositories from
          https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...}
       5. Merge metadata of 3. and 4.
       6. Upload the built and signed .deb/.rpm and the merged metadata
          for APT/Yum repositories to
          https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...}-rc
   
     For release:
       1. Download only uploaded files by 6. for RC from
          https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...}-rc
       2. Upload the downloaded files to
          https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...}


--

kou commented on pull request #11263:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11263#issuecomment-931628433


   Unfortunately, no...
   
   The current https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...} includes packages and metadata for 5.0.0.
   If we use a 5.0.0 RC, this tasks generate wrong APT/Yum repositories that include duplicated entries for 5.0.0 packages.
   
   We can test this by creating 6.0.0-alpha0.
   
   FYI: I tested general logic of this with packages.groonga.org and packages.red-data-tools.org: https://github.com/red-data-tools/packages.red-data-tools.org/blob/master/repository-task.rb


--

kszucs commented on pull request #11263:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11263#issuecomment-933396901


   > After:
   > 
   > For RC:
   > 1. Download the built .deb/.rpm for RC 
   > 2. Sign the built .deb/.rpm 
   > 3. Generate metadata for APT/Yum repositories for the built and signed .deb/.rpm 
   > 4. Download metadata for APT/Yum repositories from [https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...}](https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/%7Bdebian,centos,...%7D)
   > 5. Merge metadata of 3. and 4. 
   > 6. Upload the built and signed .deb/.rpm and the merged metadata for APT/Yum repositories to [https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/{debian,centos,...}-rc](https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/%7Bdebian,centos,...%7D-rc)
   > 
   
   Aren't the RC and non-RC repositories have the own metadata? Previously we had different versions uploaded to them.
   
   > Some problems may exist because I can't test with Artifactory. Because I don't have staging environment. I'll fix remained problems in the release process for 6.0.0.
   
   Is `packages.groonga.org` hosted on artifactory? 
   Couldn't we use a new postfix, like `{debian,centor,...}-staging` to test the new upload script on the apache artifactory account?


--

kou commented on pull request #11263:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11263#issuecomment-933994823


   > Aren't the RC and non-RC repositories have the own metadata? Previously we had different versions uploaded to them.
   
   They have own metadata.
   
   Here is workflow:
   
     * 6.0.0 RC0:
       * debian/ has metadata only for packages <= 5.0.0
       * debian-rc: has metadata for packages <= 6.0.0
     * 6.0.0:
       * debian/ has metadata for packages <= 6.0.0 (Copied from debian-rc/)
       * debian-rc/ has metadata for packages <= 6.0.0
   
   > Couldn't we use a new postfix, like `{debian,centor,...}-staging` to test the new upload script on the apache artifactory account?
   
   It's a good idea! I'll do it.


--

kou commented on pull request #11263:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11263#issuecomment-942945803


   I've pushed staging support (`STAGING=yes` environment variable enables it) and tested by the staging support.
   But the current size limit of Artifactory (100GB) isn't enough for staging support.
   If we create staging directories for {almalinux,amazon-linux,centos,debian,ubuntu}, 100GB over size is required. I tested creating staging directories for each distribution. And I deleted all staging directories for now.
   
   Removing old Python packages from https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/python/ and https://apache.jfrog.io/ui/native/arrow/python-rc/ may help us. They are largest size directories. And we already pushed them to PyPI and conda-forge. 


--

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
Running  dev/release/05-binary-upload.sh takes a long time and is prone to network failures, etc. When it fails, it needs to be started from scratch.

IMO we could alleviate this. An idea here would be to run the script in the same order of the configuration variables that it has (e.g. `UPLOAD_AMAZON_LINUX_RPM`) and echo the variable when binaries corresponding to that section are complete.

This way, when something fails, as a user I can pass r.g. `UPLOAD_AMAZON_LINUX_RPM=0` and skip the parts that were already uploaded.

comments.body:
{{dev/release/05-binary-upload.sh}} should be restartable. It should only upload failed files when we re-run it. If the current {{dev/release/05-binary-upload.sh}} isn't restartable (is always started from scratch), it's a bug.
Can I try it? Did you use {{dev/release/05-binary-upload.sh 4.0.1 1}}?

Got it. I am currently running it, so not sure how artifactory behaves. The command I am using:

```CROSSBOW_JOB_NUMBER=2 dev/release/05-binary-upload.sh 4.0.1 1```
OK. If it re-uploads uploaded files, I want to try the command line.

Can I take over this?
If it's acceptable, you can stop the script by C-c then I run the command line.
with "this" you mean fixing this bug or the release process?
I have stopped it for now fwiw as I needed to lose internet

Sorry. I meant fixing this bug and uploading binaries task.
I'll run the command line.

Got it, thanks. Yes, and thanks a lot for your fast reply and help!

This is the last step I am missing to call the vote on both source and binaries.

I'll notify you here once uploaded.
Then we can start the vote.

Uploaded. I'm verifying uploaded files.
We can't use {{dev/release/verify-release-candidate.sh}} at master because https://github.com/apache/arrow/commit/7707d333fb09fd0019a9bf03047147e05e463766 isn't suitable for 4.0.1. We can use https://github.com/apache/arrow/commit/71808f1a64789eb047ffa79be12a2984a9883334 .

{noformat}
git checkout 71808f1a64789eb047ffa79be12a2984a9883334
dev/release/verify-release-candidate.sh binaries 4.0.1 1
{noformat}

I found some ideas to improve the current behavior but doesn't implement them. Sorry. I'll work on them next week.
[~kszucs] says there may be better ways with Artifactory to do the uploading
